Statement (I) : The boiling points of alcohols and phenols increase with increase in the number of C -atoms.

In the light of the above statements, choose the correct answer from the options given below :

options.B: Both Statement I and Statement II are true
options.C: Statement I is true but Statement II is false
options.D: Both Statement I and Statement II are false

questions.question_text: 0.01 mole of an organic compound $(X)$ containing $10 \%$ hydrogen, on complete combustion produced $0.9 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{H}_2 \mathrm{O}$. Molar mass of $(\mathrm{X})$ is _________ $\mathrm{g} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$.
questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.question: 0.01 mole of an organic compound $(X)$ containing $10 \%$ hydrogen, on complete combustion produced $0.9 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{H}_2 \mathrm{O}$. Molar mass of $(\mathrm{X})$ is _________ $\mathrm{g} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$.

questions.question_text:
The bond dissociation enthalpy of $\mathrm{X}_2 \Delta \mathrm{H}_{\text {bond }}^{\circ}$ calculated from the given data is ___________ $\mathrm{kJ} \mathrm{mol}^{-1}$. (Nearest integer)

$$\begin{aligned}
& \mathrm{M}^{+} \mathrm{X}^{-}(\mathrm{s}) \rightarrow \mathrm{M}^{+}(\mathrm{g})+\mathrm{X}^{-}(\mathrm{g}) \Delta \mathrm{H}_{\text {lattice }}^{\circ}=800 \mathrm{~kJ} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1} \\
& \mathrm{M}(\mathrm{~s}) \rightarrow \mathrm{M}(\mathrm{~g}) \Delta \mathrm{H}_{\text {sub }}^{\circ}=100 \mathrm{~kJ} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}
\end{aligned}$$

$$\mathrm{M}(\mathrm{~g}) \rightarrow \mathrm{M}^{+}(\mathrm{g})+\mathrm{e}^{-}(\mathrm{g}) \Delta \mathrm{H}_{\mathrm{i}}^{\circ}=500 \mathrm{~kJ} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$$

$$\mathrm{X}(\mathrm{~g})+\mathrm{e}^{-}(\mathrm{g}) \rightarrow \mathrm{X}^{-}(\mathrm{g}) \Delta \mathrm{H}_{\mathrm{eg}}^{\circ}=-300 \mathrm{~kJ} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$$

$$\mathrm{M}(\mathrm{~s})+\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{X}_2(\mathrm{~g}) \rightarrow \mathrm{M}^{+} \mathrm{X}^{-}(\mathrm{s}) \Delta \mathrm{H}_f^{\circ}=-400 \mathrm{~kJ} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$$

[Given : $\mathrm{M}^{+} \mathrm{X}^{-}$is a pure ionic compound and X forms a diatomic molecule $\mathrm{X}_2$ in gaseous state]
questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.question:
The bond dissociation enthalpy of $\mathrm{X}_2 \Delta \mathrm{H}_{\text {bond }}^{\circ}$ calculated from the given data is ___________ $\mathrm{kJ} \mathrm{mol}^{-1}$. (Nearest integer) 
$$\begin{aligned}
& \mathrm{M}^{+} \mathrm{X}^{-}(\mathrm{s}) \rightarrow \mathrm{M}^{+}(\mathrm{g})+\mathrm{X}^{-}(\mathrm{g}) \Delta \mathrm{H}_{\text {lattice }}^{\circ}=800 \mathrm{~kJ} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1} \\
& \mathrm{M}(\mathrm{~s}) \rightarrow \mathrm{M}(\mathrm{~g}) \Delta \mathrm{H}_{\text {sub }}^{\circ}=100 \mathrm{~kJ} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}
\end{aligned}$$
$$\mathrm{M}(\mathrm{~g}) \rightarrow \mathrm{M}^{+}(\mathrm{g})+\mathrm{e}^{-}(\mathrm{g}) \Delta \mathrm{H}_{\mathrm{i}}^{\circ}=500 \mathrm{~kJ} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$$ 
$$\mathrm{X}(\mathrm{~g})+\mathrm{e}^{-}(\mathrm{g}) \rightarrow \mathrm{X}^{-}(\mathrm{g}) \Delta \mathrm{H}_{\mathrm{eg}}^{\circ}=-300 \mathrm{~kJ} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$$ 
$$\mathrm{M}(\mathrm{~s})+\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{X}_2(\mathrm{~g}) \rightarrow \mathrm{M}^{+} \mathrm{X}^{-}(\mathrm{s}) \Delta \mathrm{H}_f^{\circ}=-400 \mathrm{~kJ} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$$ 
[Given : $\mathrm{M}^{+} \mathrm{X}^{-}$is a pure ionic compound and X forms a diatomic molecule $\mathrm{X}_2$ in gaseous state]

questions.question_text:
Let $\mathrm{X}=\mathbf{R} \times \mathbf{R}$. Define a relation R on X as :

$$\left(a_1, b_1\right) R\left(a_2, b_2\right) \Leftrightarrow b_1=b_2$$

Statement I: $\quad \mathrm{R}$ is an equivalence relation.

Statement II : For some $(\mathrm{a}, \mathrm{b}) \in \mathrm{X}$, the $\operatorname{set} \mathrm{S}=\{(x, y) \in \mathrm{X}:(x, y) \mathrm{R}(\mathrm{a}, \mathrm{b})\}$ represents a line parallel to $y=x$.

In the light of the above statements, choose the correct answer from the options given below :
questions.subject: Mathematics

options.A: Both Statement I and Statement II are true
options.B: Statement I is true but Statement II is false
options.C: Both Statement I and Statement II are false
options.D: Statement I is false but Statement II is true

questions.question:
Let $\mathrm{X}=\mathbf{R} \times \mathbf{R}$. Define a relation R on X as : 
$$\left(a_1, b_1\right) R\left(a_2, b_2\right) \Leftrightarrow b_1=b_2$$ 
Statement I: $\quad \mathrm{R}$ is an equivalence relation. 
Statement II : For some $(\mathrm{a}, \mathrm{b}) \in \mathrm{X}$, the $\operatorname{set} \mathrm{S}=\{(x, y) \in \mathrm{X}:(x, y) \mathrm{R}(\mathrm{a}, \mathrm{b})\}$ represents a line parallel to $y=x$. 
In the light of the above statements, choose the correct answer from the options given below :

questions.question: $\lim \limits_{x \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\left(2 x^2-3 x+5\right)(3 x-1)^{\frac{x}{2}}}{\left(3 x^2+5 x+4\right) \sqrt{(3 x+2)^x}}$ is equal to :

questions.question_text: Let $A=\left[a_{i j}\right]$ be a $3 \times 3$ matrix such that $A\left[\begin{array}{l}0 \\ 1 \\ 0\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{l}0 \\ 0 \\ 1\end{array}\right], A\left[\begin{array}{l}4 \\ 1 \\ 3\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{l}0 \\ 1 \\ 0\end{array}\right]$ and $A\left[\begin{array}{l}2 \\ 1 \\ 2\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{l}1 \\ 0 \\ 0\end{array}\right]$, then $a_{23}$ equals :
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.question: Let $A=\left[a_{i j}\right]$ be a $3 \times 3$ matrix such that $A\left[\begin{array}{l}0 \\ 1 \\ 0\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{l}0 \\ 0 \\ 1\end{array}\right], A\left[\begin{array}{l}4 \\ 1 \\ 3\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{l}0 \\ 1 \\ 0\end{array}\right]$ and $A\left[\begin{array}{l}2 \\ 1 \\ 2\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{l}1 \\ 0 \\ 0\end{array}\right]$, then $a_{23}$ equals :

questions.question_text:
Let $\mathrm{A}=\{(x, y) \in \mathbf{R} \times \mathbf{R}:|x+y| \geqslant 3\}$ and $\mathrm{B}=\{(x, y) \in \mathbf{R} \times \mathbf{R}:|x|+|y| \leq 3\}$.
If $\mathrm{C}=\{(x, y) \in \mathrm{A} \cap \mathrm{B}: x=0$ or $y=0\}$, then $\sum_{(x, y) \in \mathrm{C}}|x+y|$ is :
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.question:
Let $\mathrm{A}=\{(x, y) \in \mathbf{R} \times \mathbf{R}:|x+y| \geqslant 3\}$ and $\mathrm{B}=\{(x, y) \in \mathbf{R} \times \mathbf{R}:|x|+|y| \leq 3\}$.
If $\mathrm{C}=\{(x, y) \in \mathrm{A} \cap \mathrm{B}: x=0$ or $y=0\}$, then $\sum_{(x, y) \in \mathrm{C}}|x+y|$ is :

questions.question_text: If in the expansion of $(1+x)^{\mathrm{p}}(1-x)^{\mathrm{q}}$, the coefficients of $x$ and $x^2$ are 1 and -2 , respectively, then $\mathrm{p}^2+\mathrm{q}^2$ is equal to :
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.question: If in the expansion of $(1+x)^{\mathrm{p}}(1-x)^{\mathrm{q}}$, the coefficients of $x$ and $x^2$ are 1 and -2 , respectively, then $\mathrm{p}^2+\mathrm{q}^2$ is equal to :

questions.question_text: A rod of length eight units moves such that its ends $A$ and $B$ always lie on the lines $x-y+2=0$ and $y+2=0$, respectively. If the locus of the point $P$, that divides the rod $A B$ internally in the ratio $2: 1$ is $9\left(x^2+\alpha y^2+\beta x y+\gamma x+28 y\right)-76=0$, then $\alpha-\beta-\gamma$ is equal to :
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.question: A rod of length eight units moves such that its ends $A$ and $B$ always lie on the lines $x-y+2=0$ and $y+2=0$, respectively. If the locus of the point $P$, that divides the rod $A B$ internally in the ratio $2: 1$ is $9\left(x^2+\alpha y^2+\beta x y+\gamma x+28 y\right)-76=0$, then $\alpha-\beta-\gamma$ is equal to :

questions.question_text: Let $\int x^3 \sin x \mathrm{~d} x=g(x)+C$, where $C$ is the constant of integration. If $8\left(g\left(\frac{\pi}{2}\right)+g^{\prime}\left(\frac{\pi}{2}\right)\right)=\alpha \pi^3+\beta \pi^2+\gamma, \alpha, \beta, \gamma \in Z$, then $\alpha+\beta-\gamma$ equals :
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.question: Let $\int x^3 \sin x \mathrm{~d} x=g(x)+C$, where $C$ is the constant of integration. If $8\left(g\left(\frac{\pi}{2}\right)+g^{\prime}\left(\frac{\pi}{2}\right)\right)=\alpha \pi^3+\beta \pi^2+\gamma, \alpha, \beta, \gamma \in Z$, then $\alpha+\beta-\gamma$ equals :

questions.question_text: A spherical chocolate ball has a layer of ice-cream of uniform thickness around it. When the thickness of the ice-cream layer is 1 cm , the ice-cream melts at the rate of $81 \mathrm{~cm}^3 / \mathrm{min}$ and the thickness of the ice-cream layer decreases at the rate of $\frac{1}{4 \pi} \mathrm{~cm} / \mathrm{min}$. The surface area (in $\mathrm{cm}^2$ ) of the chocolate ball (without the ice-cream layer) is :
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.question: A spherical chocolate ball has a layer of ice-cream of uniform thickness around it. When the thickness of the ice-cream layer is 1 cm , the ice-cream melts at the rate of $81 \mathrm{~cm}^3 / \mathrm{min}$ and the thickness of the ice-cream layer decreases at the rate of $\frac{1}{4 \pi} \mathrm{~cm} / \mathrm{min}$. The surface area (in $\mathrm{cm}^2$ ) of the chocolate ball (without the ice-cream layer) is :

questions.question_text: Let the shortest distance from $(a, 0), a>0$, to the parabola $y^2=4 x$ be 4 . Then the equation of the circle passing through the point $(a, 0)$ and the focus of the parabola, and having its centre on the axis of the parabola is :
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.question: Let the shortest distance from $(a, 0), a>0$, to the parabola $y^2=4 x$ be 4 . Then the equation of the circle passing through the point $(a, 0)$ and the focus of the parabola, and having its centre on the axis of the parabola is :

questions.question_text: Let $x=x(y)$ be the solution of the differential equation $y=\left(x-y \frac{\mathrm{~d} x}{\mathrm{~d} y}\right) \sin \left(\frac{x}{y}\right), y>0$ and $x(1)=\frac{\pi}{2}$. Then $\cos (x(2))$ is equal to :
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.question: Let $x=x(y)$ be the solution of the differential equation $y=\left(x-y \frac{\mathrm{~d} x}{\mathrm{~d} y}\right) \sin \left(\frac{x}{y}\right), y>0$ and $x(1)=\frac{\pi}{2}$. Then $\cos (x(2))$ is equal to :

questions.question_text: Let $\alpha, \beta$ be the roots of the equation $x^2-\mathrm{ax}-\mathrm{b}=0$ with $\operatorname{Im}(\alpha)<\operatorname{Im}(\beta)$. Let $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{n}}=\alpha^{\mathrm{n}}-\beta^{\mathrm{n}}$. If $\mathrm{P}_3=-5 \sqrt{7} i, \mathrm{P}_4=-3 \sqrt{7} i, \mathrm{P}_5=11 \sqrt{7} i$ and $\mathrm{P}_6=45 \sqrt{7} i$, then $\left|\alpha^4+\beta^4\right|$ is equal to __________.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.question: Let $\alpha, \beta$ be the roots of the equation $x^2-\mathrm{ax}-\mathrm{b}=0$ with $\operatorname{Im}(\alpha)<\operatorname{Im}(\beta)$. Let $\mathrm{P}_{\mathrm{n}}=\alpha^{\mathrm{n}}-\beta^{\mathrm{n}}$. If $\mathrm{P}_3=-5 \sqrt{7} i, \mathrm{P}_4=-3 \sqrt{7} i, \mathrm{P}_5=11 \sqrt{7} i$ and $\mathrm{P}_6=45 \sqrt{7} i$, then $\left|\alpha^4+\beta^4\right|$ is equal to __________.

questions.question_text: The focus of the parabola $y^2=4 x+16$ is the centre of the circle $C$ of radius 5 . If the values of $\lambda$, for which C passes through the point of intersection of the lines $3 x-y=0$ and $x+\lambda y=4$, are $\lambda_1$ and $\lambda_2, \lambda_1<\lambda_2$, then $12 \lambda_1+29 \lambda_2$ is equal to ________ .
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.question: The focus of the parabola $y^2=4 x+16$ is the centre of the circle $C$ of radius 5 . If the values of $\lambda$, for which C passes through the point of intersection of the lines $3 x-y=0$ and $x+\lambda y=4$, are $\lambda_1$ and $\lambda_2, \lambda_1<\lambda_2$, then $12 \lambda_1+29 \lambda_2$ is equal to ________ .

questions.subject: Mathematics

questions.question_text: The roots of the quadratic equation $3 x^2-p x+q=0$ are $10^{\text {th }}$ and $11^{\text {th }}$ terms of an arithmetic progression with common difference $\frac{3}{2}$. If the sum of the first 11 terms of this arithmetic progression is 88 , then $q-2 p$ is equal to ________ .
questions.subject: Mathematics

questions.question_text:
Given below are two statements. One is labelled as Assertion (A) and the other is labelled as Reason (R).

Assertion (A) : The binding energy per nucleon is found to be practically independent of the atomic number A , for nuclei with mass numbers between 30 and 170 .

Reason (R) : Nuclear force is long range.
In the light of the above statements, choose the correct answer from the options given below :
questions.subject: Physics

options.B: Both (A) and (R) are true and (R) is the correct explanation of (A)
options.D: Both (A) and (R) are true but (R) is NOT the correct explanation of (A)

questions.question:

Assertion (A) : The binding energy per nucleon is found to be practically independent of the atomic number A , for nuclei with mass numbers between 30 and 170 . 
Reason (R) : Nuclear force is long range.
In the light of the above statements, choose the correct answer from the options given below :

questions.question_text: A ball having kinetic energy KE, is projected at an angle of $60^{\circ}$ from the horizontal. What will be the kinetic energy of ball at the highest point of its flight?
questions.subject: Physics
questions.question: A ball having kinetic energy KE, is projected at an angle of $60^{\circ}$ from the horizontal. What will be the kinetic energy of ball at the highest point of its flight?

questions.question_text:
In photoelectric effect an em-wave is incident on a metal surface and electrons are ejected from the surface. If the work function of the metal is 2.14 eV and stopping potential is 2 V , what is the wavelength of the em-wave?
(Given $\mathrm{hc}=1242 \mathrm{eVnm}$ where h is the Planck's constant and c is the speed of light in vaccum.)
questions.subject: Physics
questions.question:
In photoelectric effect an em-wave is incident on a metal surface and electrons are ejected from the surface. If the work function of the metal is 2.14 eV and stopping potential is 2 V , what is the wavelength of the em-wave?
(Given $\mathrm{hc}=1242 \mathrm{eVnm}$ where h is the Planck's constant and c is the speed of light in vaccum.)

questions.question_text: Two point charges $-4 \mu \mathrm{c}$ and $4 \mu \mathrm{c}$, constituting an electric dipole, are placed at $(-9,0,0) \mathrm{cm}$ and $(9,0,0) \mathrm{cm}$ in a uniform electric field of strength $10^4 \mathrm{NC}^{-1}$. The work done on the dipole in rotating it from the equilibrium through $180^{\circ}$ is :

questions.question_text:
The width of one of the two slits in Young's double slit experiment is d while that of the other slit is $x \mathrm{~d}$. If the ratio of the maximum to the minimum intensity in the interference pattern on the screen is $9: 4$ then what is the value of $x$ ?
(Assume that the field strength varies according to the slit width.)

The errors in the measurement of $\alpha$ and $t$ are $1.2 \%$ and $1.6 \%$, respectively. At $t=5 \mathrm{~s}$, maximum percentage error in the energy is :

.tg  {border-collapse:collapse;border-spacing:0;}
.tg td{border-color:black;border-style:solid;border-width:1px;font-family:Arial, sans-serif;font-size:14px;
  overflow:hidden;padding:10px 5px;word-break:normal;}
.tg th{border-color:black;border-style:solid;border-width:1px;font-family:Arial, sans-serif;font-size:14px;
  font-weight:normal;overflow:hidden;padding:10px 5px;word-break:normal;}
.tg .tg-c3ow{border-color:inherit;text-align:center;vertical-align:top}
.tg .tg-7btt{border-color:inherit;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;vertical-align:top}
.tg .tg-0pky{border-color:inherit;text-align:left;vertical-align:top}








  
    
    List - I
    
    List - II
  

  
    (A)
    Permeability of free space
    (I)
    $\left[\mathrm{M} \mathrm{L}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right]$
  
  
    (B)
    Magnetic field
    (II)
    $\left[\mathrm{M} \mathrm{T}^{-2} \mathrm{~A}^{-1}\right]$
  
  
    (C)
    Magnetic moment
    (III)
    $\left[\mathrm{M} \mathrm{L} \mathrm{T}^{-2} \mathrm{~A}^{-2}\right]$
  
  
    (D)
    Torsional constant
    (IV)
    $\left[\mathrm{L}^2 \mathrm{~A}\right]$
  


Choose the correct answer from the options given below :

questions.question_text:

How much power is delivered by the applied torque, when $t=2 \mathrm{~s}$ ?
questions.subject: Physics

questions.question_text: A time varying potential difference is applied between the plates of a parallel plate capacitor of capacitance $2.5 \mu \mathrm{~F}$. The dielectric constant of the medium between the capacitor plates is 1 . It produces an instantaneous displacement current of 0.25 mA in the intervening space between the capacitor plates, the magnitude of the rate of change of the potential difference will be _________ $\mathrm{Vs}^{-1}$.

questions.question_text: A satellite of mass $\frac{M}{2}$ is revolving around earth in a circular orbit at a height of $\frac{R}{3}$ from earth surface. The angular momentum of the satellite is $\mathrm{M} \sqrt{\frac{\mathrm{GMR}}{x}}$. The value of $x$ is _________ , where M and R are the mass and radius of earth, respectively. ( G is the gravitational constant)
